title: 114_s2134
content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants to be employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience and a degree in a health-related field. The pilot program selects eligible individuals with health-related degrees and military health experience to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. At least 250 individuals will be chosen over a five-year period, with priority given to certain candidates. The pilot program selects individuals with health-related degrees and military health experience to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Priority is given to those who participated in a previous program or agree to work in underserved communities with a high veteran population. The pilot program provides educational assistance for individuals with health-related degrees to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies. The Secretary will use existing VA educational assistance programs to cover the costs for participants. The Department of Veterans Affairs offers educational assistance programs for individuals to become physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration. Participants in the pilot program receive scholarships and agree to a period of obligated service. Participants in the pilot program for physician assistants with the Veterans Health Administration have a specified period of obligated service. If the program does not specify a period, individuals must serve for three years or a period determined by the Secretary. Failure to fulfill the obligated service results in liability to the United States. Participants in the pilot program for physician assistants with the Veterans Health Administration must fulfill a specified period of obligated service. Failure to do so results in liability to the United States, with exceptions for certain programs. The Secretary ensures availability of physician assistant mentors at each facility. The Secretary ensures physician assistant mentors are available for participants in the pilot program at Veterans Health Administration facilities. Partnerships with accredited institutions of higher education are sought to guarantee seats in master's degree programs for program participants. The pilot program aims to provide information on admissions criteria for a master's degree program and collaborate with accredited institutions for physician assistant studies. Additionally, it involves partnerships with the Transition Assistance Program, Veterans' Employment and Training Service, and marketing efforts to attract veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary will oversee the administration of the pilot program within the Office of Physician Assistant Services at Veterans Health Administration facilities. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Office of Physician Assistant Services. The Deputy Director is responsible for overseeing, recruiting candidates, coordinating with participants, and assisting in applying to a master's degree program under the pilot program. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran employed by the Department, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program, providing mentors, and identifying employment positions within the Veterans Health Administration. The pilot program participants may be employed at a medical center of the Department. A recruiter reports to the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention to develop national recruiting plans for physician assistants. An administrative assistant, compensated at a rate not less than level GS-6, supports the recruitment efforts. The pilot program for recruiting and retaining physician assistants in the Department includes an administrative assistant at a GS-6 level to assist with administrative duties. A report on the program's effectiveness must be submitted to Congress within one year. The pilot program aims to improve the ability of eligible individuals to become physician assistants, help meet the shortage of physician assistants in the Department, and identify necessary modifications for achieving program goals. The pilot program aims to improve the ability of eligible individuals to become physician assistants and address the shortage of physician assistants in the Department. Not less than $8,000,000 of the funding for the program will come from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretaries of Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services will assess if the program can be a model for other healthcare fields. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department of Veterans Affairs. This includes holding medical center directors accountable for program utilization and providing incentives for employee advancement and recruitment. The Education Debt Reduction Program will also be available for participants. The Department of Veterans Affairs will ensure the availability of the Education Debt Reduction Program for physician assistants to fill vacant positions, monitor compliance with educational assistance programs, and create new programs for employee incentives and scholarships. The Department of Veterans Affairs will create programs to encourage employees to apply to physician assistant programs, with the Secretary prescribing necessary regulations. Establishment of pay grades for physician assistants of the Department of Veterans Affairs and requirement to provide competitive pay. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs and the requirement to provide competitive pay. It includes amendments to ensure competitive pay for physician assistants and the implementation of a national strategic plan for their retention and recruitment. The Secretary must report to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs within a year of enacting the Act regarding the implementation of a national strategic plan for physician assistants' pay in comparison to the private sector.
